text.p: These are the leading stories in the Zambian press on Friday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The Zambia National Oil Company is building up fuel stocks to avert a shortage when it shuts down the national petroluem refinery plant for maintenance.
- The ministry of agriculture has advised farmers to explore the possibility of exploiting the Kenyan market.
- The University of Zambia is to investigate the causes behind frequent student disturbances leading to unscheduled closures of the institution.

- Opposition parties, challenging the legitimacy of last years elections, propose that President Frederick Chiluba and a man who claims to be his biological father, be DNA tested to establish the presidents true origins. The opposition claims the President lied about his nationality and parentage in filing his electoral nomination papers.

- Zambia is among several African countries that will benefit from a $250,000 training kit for drug detector dogs in a United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) initiative to combat drug trafficking.
- The tourism council has asked government to give it a five- year tax holiday.
